name: MONKSHOOD
description: 5 showy blue to purple sepals, with the upper sepal forming the hood.
habitat: forest openings, wet meadows and thickets.

name: SMALL-FLOWERED STICKLEAF
description: leaves sessile (without a stalk), with shallow and regularly scalloped margins.
habitat: dry sites.

name: WILD BLUE FLAX
description: stigma capitate (headed); plant produces many branches from the base; styles of same length on different plants.
habitat: dry slopes, forest clearings, roadsides.

name: BURNT-ORANGE AGOSERIS
description: leaves basal, somewhat lobed or toothed; heads with ray flowers only.
habitat: meadows

name: FALSE DANDELION
description: outer phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - below a composite flower head) erect; flowers all ligulate (strap-shaped). Var. laciniata has a scape (flowering stem) less than 2 dm tall, pinnatifid (divided like a feather along a main axis) and a narrow head. Var. dasycephala is a tall coarse plant with large wooly heads.
habitat: dry meadows and open slopes.

name: SASKATOON SERVICEBERRY
description: upright, arching branches form a rounded crown; leaves broadly ovate (egg-shaped), sharply rounded at the base; flowers in axillary (where the leaf joins the stem) clusters; leaves and twigs glabrous (hairless) in age.
habitat: forested parts of mountains.

name: YELLOW STONECROP
description: leaves succulent (fleshy), in basal (at the plant base) clusters, often deciduous (falling off, not persistent throughout the year) before anthesis (opening of the flower).
habitat: rocky ground at 5,000 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: DWARF  PUSSYTOES
description: usually with leafy stolons; leaves in basal rosette, white-tomentose on both sides (densely covered with thick-wooly hairs with no distinct orientation); phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding composite head) white or sometimes pinkish tips.
habitat: open montane forests.

name: PINK PUSSYTOES
description: mat-forming usually with leafy stolons (stem running along surface of the ground); leaves in a basal rosette are white-tomentose on both sides (densely covered with thick-wooly hairs with no distinct orientation); phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding a composite head) pink or white.
habitat: forested areas.

name: RED THREE-AWN
description: glumes (basal empty bracts - small leaf-like structures - enclosing the base of grass spikelet - smallest flower cluster) unequal, the first half as long as the second.
habitat: dry hills, disturbed sited at 2,700 to 7,600 feet elevation.

name: FRINGED MOUNTAIN SAGE
common_name: fringed sage, silver sage, wormwood, pasture sage
description: leaves finely dissected, silvery-hairy; flowering stems erect.
habitat: dry meadows and slopes at 3,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: PRAIRIE SAGE
description: leaves silver white to greenish.
habitat: dry plains, roadcuts at 4,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: FOUR-WINGED SALTBUSH
description: shrubby throughout; fruit bracts (small leaf-like structures) with the margins spreading apart, creating four wings; plant widely and stiffly branched.
habitat: sagebrush zone and greasewood flats on the plains and San Luis Valley; sandy and alkaline areas at 4,000 to 8,000 feet.

name: AMERICAN BISTORT
common_name: bistort, western bistort, smartweed, knotweed, snakeweed
description: white flowers in a dense cyclindric raceme; (elongated flower cluster with stalked flowers along a main axis); erect slender stem.
habitat: moist or wet meadows and swamps at high elevations.

name: GUNNISON MARIPOSA
description: cup-shaped flower with 3 petals and 3 sepals; petals with dark hairy spot at their base.
habitat: aspen groves, meadows on the Eastern Slope

name: HAREBELL
description: corolla lobed only about 1/3; stems over 2 dm tall; flowers several per stem.
habitat: dry mountain slopes at lower to middle altitudes (7,500 to 11,500 feet).

name: COLORFUL INDIAN PAINTBRUSH
description: stems erect, leafy to the slender root crown; bracts (small leaf-like structures) and leaves little incised, softly pilose (having long soft hairs); lower lip and most of the galea (upper lip of bilaterially symmetrical corollas) usually included in the calyx tube; fresh roots yellow.
habitat: deep sandy loam, sagebrush, valleys, drylands at 4,000 to 9,000 feet elevation.

name: WYOMING PAINTBRUSH
description: leaves linear, bracts red; calyx (ring of sepals) incised much more deeply below than above.
habitat: open meadows, forest openings, aspen groves, sagebrush at 4,000 to 10,500 feet elevation.

name: MOUSE-EAR CHICKWEED
description: floral stems with tufts of sterile shoots in leaf axils (angle where leaves join stems); bracts (small leaf-like structures) of the inflorescence (flower cluster) with scarious (dry, thin, papery) margins.
habitat: meadows and openings in pine forests.

name: MOUNTAIN MAHOGANY
description: leaves densely pubescent (hairy) underneath.
habitat: dry, rocky slopes at 4,500 to 9,000 feet.

name: COMMON FIREWEED
description: raceme (flower cluster with stalked flowers along a main axis) not leafy; styles hairy at the base, exceeding the stamens.
habitat: burned areas, roadsides, forest openings.

name: BLUE  MUSTARD
description: basal (at base of the plant) leaves are dentate (toothed with teeth projecting outward rather than forward).
habitat: fallow fields

name: SPOTTED SAXIFRAGE
description: white petals dotted with purplish red spots; leaves mostly basal, tightly stacked.
habitat: dry areas, along trails, rocky slopes, forest openings and boulder fields.

name: WESTERN VIRGIN'S BOWER
description: tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals) 4 and thin; flowers imperfect (either male or female); styles becoming long and feathery in fruit.
habitat: valley bottoms; riparian areas at 4,000 to 7,500 feet.

name: ROSE CROWN
description: flowers in dense clusters, rose colored, resembling red clover; numerous fleshy stem leaves; stout rootstock; in colonies.
habitat: in bogs, seeps, and moist ground of meadows, along streams and pond shores.

name: BLUE-EYED MARY
description: small widely branched plant with  maroon color on the stems and on the underside of the leaves.
habitat: open forests, disturbed areas.

name: TINY TRUMPET
description: leaves lanceolate (lance-shaped); flowers in a dense terminal cluster surrounded by enlarged, leaf-like bracts (small leaf-like structures).
habitat: roadsides, grasslands, disturbed areas.

name: BASTARD-TOADFLAX
description: leaves alternate (one at each node or point of attachment to the stem), bluish-green.
habitat: dry, sandy slopes, open woods, sagebrush ecosystems.

name: GOLDEN SMOKE
description: sepals 2, minute; petals separate (not united at any point in the corolla); flowers racemose (in racemes i.e stalked flowers attached along a main axis).
habitat: disturbed soil in roadbanks and ravines.

name: SUBALPINE LARKSPUR
description: fragrant flowers in terminal, sipke-like cluster with small, purple, white-margined petals and 5 deep purple sepals; upper sepal has 3/8in long spur; leaves have 5-7 coarsely toothed lobes.
habitat: moist places such as bogs, stream banks, meadows, seeps, ponds, and forest openings.

name: TWINBERRY
description: flowers seated in conspicuous, leaflike cup of bracts (small leaf-like structures).
habitat: along mountain streams and moist slopes at 6,000 to 10,000 feet.

name: CLARETCUP
description: Flowers scarlet; petals rounded and cupped; stems numerous.  Produces several short cylindrical stems from which brilliant flowers arise on the sides.
habitat: open, rocky slopes at 3,200 to 9,000 feet.

name: SQUIRRELTAIL
description: two spikelets (in grasses, the smallest flower cluster) per node; glumes (basal empty bracts - small leaf-like structures - enclosing the base of grass spikelet - smallest flower cluster) and lemmas (outer bract of grass floret) awned (containing a stiff bristlelike appendage), the awns long and spreading.
habitat: dry hillsides, open woodlands, rocky slopes, distrubed sites at 3,500 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: BRANCHING ERIGERON
description: flowers numerous and pinkish; pappus (hair-like extension of the ovary) of ray and disk flowers alike; stem pubescence (hairs) widely spreading; stems with relatively few branches.
habitat: ruderal (disturbed) areas and gravelly floodplains.

name: WHIPLASH DAISY
common_name: whiplash erigeron, trailing daisy, trailing fleabane
description: stolons ( horizontal stems that take root as in the strawberry) rooting at the tips; stem hairs appressed (lying flat); pappus (hairlike extension of the ovary) of 2 rows of bristles of different lengths.
habitat: dry meadows at 6,500 to 10,500 feet elevation.

name: SHOWY DAISY
description: upper and middle stem leaves glabrous except for ciliate margins (edged with hairs); plants uniformly leafy with middle leaves as large as lower leaves.
habitat: aspen groves, forest margins and openings at 6,000 to 11,000 feet..

name: SULPHUR FLOWER
description: grows in broad, loose mats; perianth (petals and sepals) narrowed at the base to a stipe (stalk) and externally glabrous (smooth).
habitat: forest openings, dry meadows, rocky slopes at 5,000 to 11,500 feet.

name: REDSTEM FILAREE
description: carpel (seed pod section) tails hairy on inner side; leaves pinnately compound.
habitat: disturbed sites

name: ALPINE WALLFLOWER
description: siliques (fruits) almost glabrous (hairless) and ascending, nearly parallel to the stem although pedicels (stalks) may spread widely.
habitat: gravelly slopes and hillsides and forest openings.

name: GLACIER LILY
description: leaves appearing basal, cauline (stem) leaves when opposite, much reduced; leaves elliptical; flowers yellow.
habitat: near melting snowbanks along streams, meadows, and in aspen groves at 5,500 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: GREEN GENTIAN
description: fleshy leaves in whorls; blooming plant tall, up to 6 ft.; flowers greenish-white.
habitat: pine forests and meadows.

name: BLANKETFLOWER
description: grows in clumps with erect or spreading stems; pappus (extension of the ovary) twice as long as the basal scale; leaves stiff-hairy.
habitat: meadows, hillsides, open areas at 7,000 to 9,500 feet elevation.

name: BEDSTRAW
description: leaves lanceolate (lance-shaped), blunt-tipped, 4 at a node (point on a stem where leaves or branches occur); inflorescence (flower cluster) pyramidal.
habitat: moist meadows and woodlands.

name: RICHARDSON GERANIUM
description: petals white with purple veins, pilose (having long, soft hairs) on the lower half; plant erect with a single or a few stems.
habitat: moist, shaded areas; aspen groves, spruce-fir forests.

name: SNAKEWEED
description: low and bushy growth form; phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding flower heads in the sunflower family) covered with a sticky exudate.
habitat: dry sites at low altitudes (4,000 to 7,000 feet).

name: CHAINPOD
description: upper calyx lobes slender, subequal to the lower ones and to the calyx tube; basal lobe of the wing-petals broad, much shorter than the claws, not joined over the ovary; pods plainly cross-corrugated (wrinkles or folds), the reticulations (networks) laterally elongated.
habitat: soil embankments at 4,000 to 8,000 feet elevation.

name: SUNSPOTS
description: leaves opposite, narrowly elliptic (oval), bristly; flowering heads arranged in a cyme (opposite-branched with central, terminal head blooming first).
habitat: roadsides, dry hillsides and forest openings at 4,500 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: COMMON ALUMROOT
description: stamens shorter than the sepals.
habitat: cliffs and rock outcrops.

name: ROCK SPIREA
description: flowers in terminal, many-flowered panicles (repeatedly branched flower clusters).
habitat: shaded cliff-faces, rocky slopes, hillsides, riverbottoms at 4,500 to 11,000 feet.

name: FENDLER WATERLEAF
description: leaves with sharply serrate (with forward-pointing teeth, like a saw) lobes.
habitat: streamside woodlands.

name: FAIRY TRUMPET
common_name: skyrocket, scarlet gilia (red form), white gilia
description: ovary with 3 locules (compartments); corolla (petals) salverform (with a long narrow tube opening into a wider cup i.e. trumpet-shaped).
habitat: gravelly open areas.

name: WILD IRIS
description: ovary inferior (petals and other floral parts attached at the top of the ovary).
habitat: moist open areas, wet meadows, streamsides at 4,500 to 9,500 feet elevation.

name: NARROW-LEAF PUCCOON
common_name: fringed gromwell, fringed puccoon, narrowleaf gromwell, narrowleaf stoneseed, puccoon
description: corolla (petals) tube 3 - 4 times longer than the calyx (sepals); corolla salverform (trumpet-shaped); corolla lobes fringed.
habitat: dry slopes and valleys.

name: SILVERY LUPINE
description: tip of keel (lower petal in pea family) long and slender, erect or slanting forward; leaves are palmately compound (divided like a hand); leaflets often conduplicate (folded lengthwise).
habitat: open forests, hillsides and slopes.

name: HOARY TANSY ASTER
common_name: tansy aster, sticky aster, hoary aster
description: phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - that subtend a composite flower head) with the ends recurved (bent backwards); glandular (sticky) hairs lacking on the peduncles (stalk of the composite head) and phyllaries (bracts below heads).
habitat: roadsides

name: CREEPING HOLLYGRAPE
common_name: Oregon grape, holly-grape, creeping oregon grape
description: above-ground stem short or lacking; leaflets broad with a few spiny teeth.
habitat: uplands and open coniferous forests.

name: FALSE SOLOMON SEAL
common_name: claspleaf solomon's plume, many-flowered false solomon seal
description: leaves clasping and broadly oval; flowers numerous in a dense panicle (branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).
habitat: streamsides, moist meadows and gulches.

name: WILD LILY-OF-THE-VALLEY
common_name: star solomon's seal; star solomon's plume, few-flowered false solomon seal
description: flowers in a raceme (stalked flowers along a main axis).
habitat: shady, moist areas in the forested mountains.

name: BLACK MEDIC
description: plants decumbent (lying flat on the ground except for the ascending tips of the branches); leaves trifoliolate (having 3 leaflets).
habitat: disturbed areas, lawns, gardens, meadows.

name: CHIMING BELLS
description: leaves glabrous (hairless), sometimes with papillae (tiny wart-like structures) above.
habitat: streamsides, near springs, ponds and other very moist areas.

name: SNOWBALL SAXIFRAGE
description: leaves rhomboid (shaped like an equilateral parallelogram), tapering to a short, broad petiole (leaf stalk).
habitat: open areas and rocky slopes that are seasonally moist in spring.

name: WILD FOUR-O'CLOCK
description: leaves cordate (heart-shaped); plants procumbent (trailing on the ground).
habitat: open canyonsides and roadsides at 3,000 to 7,500 feet elevation.

name: STEMLESS EVENING-PRIMROSE
description: plant stemless; leaves in a basal rosette, to 6 inches, with toothed or wavy margins.
habitat: dry slopes, prairies, near anthills at 3,000 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: PRICKLY-PEAR CACTUS
description: pads very spiny, not wrinkled; fruits dry and withering soon after ripening.
habitat: sunny, rocky slopes at 3,500 to 7,200 feet elevation.

name: FERNLEAF LOUSEWORT
description: much less than 3 feet tall; flowers not streaked with reddish; corolla less than 1.5 inch long; lower lip not reaching the tip of the galea (hood-shaped sepal or petal).
habitat: dry spruce-fir forests.

name: ELEPHANT HEAD
description: flower resembles an elephant's head; flowers in an elongated spike (unstalked flowers along a main axis).
habitat: Wet meadows, bogs

name: PONDEROSA PINE
description: needles in packages (fascicles) of 3 or 2; female cones large, up to 6 inches long; male cones up to 2 inches long.
habitat: exposed hillsides, mesas, and south-facing slopes.

name: LEAFY JACOB'S LADDER
description: corolla (whorl of petals) campanulate (bell-shaped); leaves mostly cauline (on stem); leaflets pubescent (hairy).
habitat: streamsides and meadows.

name: SILVERY POTENTILLA
description: leaves pinnate with toothed leaflets, silvery-pubescent, often bi-colored; flowers 0.5 inch diameter; stems tufted.
habitat: dry hillsides, gravelly slopes, trailsides, forest edges.

name: JAMES STARWORT
description: dark colored anthers are visible against petals; leaves lanceolate; plant glandular-pubescent (sticky-hairy).
habitat: forest edges, meadows, slopes.

name: MARSH MARIGOLD
description: erect leafless flower stalk, white flower with prominent yellow center.
habitat: large patches in bogs, marshes, soggy meadows, along lakes and ponds.

name: WINGED BUCKWHEAT
description: basal leaves oblanceolate (lance-shaped, with the broadest part at the apex); flower cluster a panicle (repeatedly branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).
habitat: open hillsides, mesas and mountain parks.

name: PASQUE FLOWER
description: tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals) overlapping; upper stem leaves form a whorl below the flower; leaves and stems pubescent (hairy).
habitat: open forests at 8,500 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: GAMBEL OAK
description: leaves usually over 2 inches long, not rigid.
habitat: foothills, Jefferson County and south at 5,000 to 9,000 feet elevation.

name: THREE-LEAF SUMAC
description: arching branches form dense, rounded shrub.  Red, hairy fruits; 3-parted leaves resemble poison ivy, to which skunkbrush is related, on a smaller scale.
habitat: canyonsides and rimrock at 4,000 to 8,000 feet elevation.l

name: MOUNTAIN GOOSEBERRY
description: stems with both prickles and spines; hypanthium (fused bases of stamens, petals and sepals) tubular.
habitat: shaded, moist areas at 6,000 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: RED PRICKLY CURRANT
description: low spreading shrub; leaves pubescent and glandular; spines 3 at node.
habitat: wet meadows and willow fens.

name: WOODS ROSE
description: leaflets 5 - 7; flowering stems with broad-based thorns, occasional bristles; sepals 2 mm wide at base.
habitat: valleys, gulches, trailsides at 6,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: WILD RED RASPBERRY
description: stems with prickles; leaves glaucous (contains white waxy covering) underneath.
habitat: moist forests and slopes.

name: EARLY SPRING SENECIO
common_name: common spring senecio, lambstongue groundsel, tall golden ragwort
description: pubescent (hairy), losing most pubescence in age; terminal head shorter than others.
habitat: moist meadows and slopes.

name: COWBOY'S DELIGHT
common_name: copper mallow, scarlet globemallow, scarlet falsemallow
description: lower leaves very deeply palmately (like a hand) divided, silvery from dense, stellate (star-shaped) hairs.
habitat: roadsides, disturbed areas at 4,500 to 8,500 feet elevation.

name: FENDLER MEADOWRUE
description: flowers mostly unisexual (either male or female); anthers much longer than wide; upper and lower edges of fruits mostly convex.
habitat: meadows, aspen groves from 5,000 to 9,500 feet elevation.

name: YELLOW SALSIFY
description: flowers shorter than the phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - below a composite flower head); peduncles (stalk of a flower cluster) swollen in fruit.
habitat: dry, hot valleys.

name: STINGING NETTLE
description: leaves opposite (in pairs) glabrous (hairless) on upper surface with stinging hairs on lower surface.
habitat: streamsides, irrigation ditches.

name: MOUNTAIN BLUEBERRY
description: leaves more than 10 mm., serrate from base to end; branchlets angled, green.
habitat: forest openings and rocky areas, 7500 - 12,500 ft.

name: EARLY BLUE VIOLET
description: leaves pubescent (hairy); leaves seldom clearly cordate (heart-shaped).
habitat: meadows, streamsides, aspen groves.

name: NUTTALL VIOLET
description: leaves narrowly lanceolate (lance-shaped) or lance-elliptic (oval), at least 3 times long as wide.
habitat: meadows, open slopes, often blooming in the protection of rocks at 5,000 to 11,500 feet elevation.
